title: 114_s599
content: The "Improving Access to Emergency Psychiatric Care Act" extends and expands the Medicaid Emergency Psychiatric Demonstration Project for a period of 3 consecutive years, with a temporary extension of participation eligibility for selected states. The "Improving Access to Emergency Psychiatric Care Act" extends the Medicaid Emergency Psychiatric Demonstration Project for selected states until September 30, 2016, if certain conditions are met. The Secretary must determine that state participation will not increase program spending, and the Chief Actuary must certify the same. States will be notified of their eligibility by March 13, 2012. The Secretary may allow eligible states to continue participating in the Medicaid Emergency Psychiatric Demonstration Project until December 31, 2019, if it is projected not to increase program spending and certified by the Chief Actuary. Medicaid Services certifies that the State's participation in the demonstration project is not expected to increase program spending under title XIX of the Social Security Act. The Secretary has the option to expand the number of eligible States in the project until December 31, 2019, if the State's participation is projected not to increase program spending. The Chief Actuary of the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services must certify that a State's participation in a demonstration project will not increase net program spending under title XIX of the Social Security Act. The Secretary is required to notify each State participating in the project and any additional State applying to join, providing details of the certification and standards used for the determination. The Secretary must review each State's demonstration project expenditures annually to ensure compliance with budget neutrality requirements. If a State's net program spending under title XIX of the Social Security Act increases as a result of participation, the Secretary will take action. The Secretary will treat demonstration project excess expenditures of the State as an overpayment under title XIX of the Social Security Act. Funding for the project is amended to be available until expended, with certain limitations removed. The Secretary will make payments to eligible States, including those deemed eligible through subsection (c)(4). The payments will be made during specific periods and under certain laws, in addition to any previous payments made. The Secretary will make payments to eligible States for emergency psychiatric demonstration services, treated as medical assistance under the State plan. Recommendations to Congress regarding extension and expansion of the project must be submitted by September 30, 2016. The Secretary will submit recommendations to Congress and the public based on an evaluation of the demonstration project, including quality measures, regarding whether to continue the project after September 30, 2016, and expand it to additional States. Additionally, recommendations on permanent extension and nationwide expansion must be submitted by April 1, 2019. The Secretary will submit recommendations to Congress and the public based on an evaluation of the demonstration project, including quality measures, regarding whether to permanently continue or expand the project to additional States. Congressional approval is required for permanent continuation in any State. The demonstration project must not continue in any State after December 31, 2019, or expand to additional States without Congressional approval. Any State's participation must comply with budget neutrality requirements, and excess expenditures will be treated as overpayments under title XIX of the Social Security Act. Funding will come from unobligated balances in the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services Program. Funding of $100,000 from unobligated balances in the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services Program Management account is available for the subsection. Section 2707 of the Act is amended to include provisions for publicly or privately run institutions for mental diseases. Eligible States must comply with budget neutrality requirements for participation in the project. The amendments made by this section, including nationwide availability and effective date, will take effect upon enactment of the Act.
